Question: 1.	What is the thickness of the crust under the mountainous areas and in particular the Himalayas?
Explanation: Explanation: It is believed that the thickness of the crust under the Himalayas is 70 to 75 km and under the Hindukush it is said to be 60 km thick.

Question: 2.	The discontinuity which marks the lower boundary of the crust is
Explanation: Explanation: Mohorovicic discontinuity marks the lower boundary of the crust which is the first layer of the Earth.

Question: 3.	The granite layer in the crust is also referred to as
Explanation: Explanation: SIAL stands for Silicon and Aluminium and as per the name it is made up of the two elements and hence the name.

Question: 4.	The density of the oceanic layer in the crust is said to be
Explanation: Explanation: The oceanic crust is estimated to have a volume of 2.54*109 cc with an average density of 3.00 g/cc.

Question: 5.	The depth at which the Mohorovicic discontinuity occurs is
Explanation: Explanation: Mohorovicic discontinuity from seismic evidence is determined that it is approximately at a depth of 30-40 km.

Question: 6.	What is the speed attained by the P-waves in the C-layer under the Continental crust?
Explanation: Explanation: The C-layer is the lowermost layer of the continental crust and here the P-waves attain velocity as high as 6 to 7.6 km/sec.

Question: 7.	The layer under the continental crust with the density of 2.4 to 2.6 g/cc
Explanation: Explanation: The Middle layer or B-layer of the continental crust is relatively dense compared to A-layer and the density is said to be 2.4 to 2.6 g/cc.

Question: 8.	The expansion of SIMA is
Explanation: Explanation: Silicon and Magnesium. The C-layer under the continental crust is rich in Silicon and Magnesium and hence the layer is also sometimes called SIMA.

Question: 10.	The least dense layer among the layers under  the continental crust is
Explanation: Explanation: The A or the upper layer is between 2 to 10 km thick and is of low density, 2.00 g/cc.

Question: 11.	The area not considered under the crust is
Explanation: Explanation: The first the options, Mountainous, Continental and Oceanic areas are studied separately whereas Glacial area is not considered under study of the crust as such.

Question: 1.	The depth up to which the mantle is said to exist is ________
Explanation: Explanation: The second layer, Mantle, lies beneath the crust and this zone starting from the lower boundary of the crust continues up to a depth of 2,900 km.

Question: 2.	The thickness of the 2 layers of the upper mantle is approximately said to be
Explanation: Explanation:  The upper mantle is further divided into two layers of 400 and 600 km thickness respectively.

Question: 4.	Which of the following is not true about Asthenosphere?
Option A: a)	It is present in the upper mantle
Option B: b)	It is in solid state
Option C: c)	It is the source of volcanic activity
Option D: d)	It is in plastic rather than solid state
Explanation: Explanation: It is in solid state is not true and the remaining options are true and they are characteristics of the asthenosphere. In Greek, “asthenes” means without strength and hence the name.

Question: 5.	Who was the first person to tell about the Core?
Explanation: Explanation:  The existence of the core was suggested by R.D. Oldham in 1906 and subsequently confirmed by other seismologists.

Question: 6.	The depth at which the core layer starts and ends respectively is ____________
Explanation: Explanation:  The mantle extends up to the depth of 2900 km and from that depth it is the core that is said to be present and the radius of the Earth is 6371 km and hence the core is said to extend till 6371 km.

Question: 7.	Which of the following is true about the inner core?
Option A: a)	It is believed to be a semi solid body
Option B: b)	It is believed to be a solid body
Option C: c)	It is believed to be a liquid body
Option D: d)	It is believed to be a gaseous body.
Explanation: Explanation:  The inner core with a thickness of around 1790 km is believed to be a solid body.

Question: 8.	The density of the Earth in the core immediately after the mantle is _______
Explanation: Explanation:  At the base of the mantle, density is inferred as 5.7 g/cc that jumps to 9.9 g/cc at the top of the core.

Question: 9.	The layer which does not transmit the S-waves is _______
Explanation: Explanation:  The outer core behaves more like a liquid because the S-waves from the earthquake shocks reaching this zone are not transmitted through this zone at all.

Question: 11.	The density of the Earth at its centre is said to be
Explanation: Explanation:  The value of density reaches 12.7 g/cc at the boundary of the inner core and becomes 13 g/cc at the centre of the Earth.

Question: 12.	The layer which is said to support the slow moving tectonic plates is
Explanation: Explanation: The Asthenosphere is believed to be located entirely in the upper mantle and supports the slowly moving tectonic plates.

Question: 13.	What is the thickness of the inner core?
Explanation: Explanation:  The inner core, is believed to be in solid metallic state and is said have thickness of about 1790 km.

Question: 14.	The layer which is believed to be the source of volcanic activity is
Explanation: Explanation: The asthenosphere is believed to be the source of much volcanic activity and many other processes. It is is said be to located completely in the upper mantle.

Question: 1. Which of the following about weathering is not true?
Option A: a) It is a natural process
Option D: d) It is a rapid process
Explanation: Explanation: Weathering is defined as, a natural process of in-situ mechanical disintegration and or chemical decomposition of the rocks of the crust of the Earth by certain physical and chemical agencies of the atmosphere. It is a very slow process.

Question: 2. The process that is not considered under mechanical weathering is _______
Explanation: Explanation: Carbonation is a chemical weathering process whereas the rest viz., temperature variation, unloading, insolation are processes of mechanical weathering.

Question: 3. What is the change in volume when water freezes?
Explanation: Explanation: It is said that, water on freezing undergoes an increase in its volume by about ten per cent. This is expansion is accompanied by exertion of pressure.

Question: 4. The form of rock not found by freezing-thawing cycle is ________
Explanation: Explanation: The frost formed fragments are angular, sub angular, irregular in outline and remain spread over the parent rock having flat surface or flat slopes. Spherical form or outline of rock doesn’t come into picture here.

Question: 5. The processes by which Scree deposits are formed are
Explanation: Explanation: If the original surface forms a significant slope, as is commonly the case in the hilly and mountainous regions, the frost fragments get heaved up from the crevices and cavities and then roll down the slope under the influence of gravity. Finally, the fragments accumulate at the base as heaps commonly called as Scree deposits.

Question: 6. What are the slopes covered by Scree called?
Explanation: Explanation: The slopes covered by frost formed scree are often referred to as Talus slopes.

Question: 7. Where can one find the process of exudation occur?
Explanation: Explanation: Exudation is a process similar to frost action but in this case disintegration takes place due to the formation of sodium chloride etc., within the cavities of rocks thereby causing disintegration. This process is seen in good measure in porous rocks near seashore.

Question: 8. The stress developed in the top layers of the rocks which disintegrate due to repeated variations in temperatures is________
Explanation: Explanation: Repeated variations in temperature experienced by a body of rock gradually break it into smaller pieces, especially in the top layers, by development of tensile stresses developing from alternate expansion and contraction.

Question: 9. Which of the following facts about Exfoliation is false?
Option A: a) It is the phenomenon of peeling off of curved shells from rocks
Option B: b) The change is accompanied by chemical weathering
Option C: c) Internal structure of the rock is affected
Option D: d) It occurs in thick or layered rocks.
Explanation: Explanation: The internal structure of the rock is not affected due to the process of exfoliation. The phenomenon of peeling off occurs only in the layered or thick rocks and is accompanied by chemical weathering, mostly near the margins and develop curved surfaces. So basically surface is affected and not the internal structure.

Question: 10. The large-scale development of fracturing in confined rock masses occurs under which process?
Explanation: Answer: The process of mechanical weathering where large-scale development of fracturing in confined rock masses is attributed to removal of the overlying rock cover due to prolonged erosional work of other agencies is called unloading.

Question: 11. The formation of sheets and subsequently joints occurs in which of the following processes?
Explanation: Explanation: The rock masses under the effect of unloading remain confined from sides but due to relief of pressure from above, they expand upwards; consequently joints develop in them parallel to the uncovered surface dividing them into sheets.

Question: 14. In Kara Qum desert, the rocks are exposed to what temperatures in summer and winter respectively?
Explanation: Explanation: Studies have shown that in desert like Kara Qum, rocks are exposed to as high temperatures as 70-80° C in summer and are then cooled down to -10° C in winter. Such repeated variations in temperature experienced by a body of rock gradually break it into smaller pieces.

Question: 1. The main processes which does not come under chemical weathering are
Explanation: Explanation: The processes, solution, hydration and hydrolysis, carbonation are all chemical processes and involve chemical reaction, whereas, insolation is a process of mechanical weathering.

Question: 2. The rock-mineral insoluble in water is
Explanation: Explanation: Pyrite is insoluble in water, whereas, rock salt, gypsum and calcite are examples of minerals that are soluble in water to some extent.

Question: 4. Minerals like Orthoclase and Felspar undergo which method of chemical decomposition?
Explanation: Explanation: Ions may be exchanged whereby some ions from water may enter into the crystal lattice of the mineral. This process of exchange of ions is called hydrolysis. It is a very common process of weathering of silicate minerals and is best explained with reference to weathering of mineral Orthoclase, Felspar.

Question: 5. Which of the following is reduction?
Explanation: Explanation: Oxidation means of either removal of electron or hydrogen or addition of oxygen but, reduction may involve removal of oxygen or addition of hydrogen or electron.

Question: 6. 2KaISi3O8   +   2H2O     +   CO2 _ Al2Si2O5(OH)4   +   K2CO3   +   4SiO2
Option A: Orthoclase  +  Carbonic acid      _    ___________    +  Pot. Carbonate + Silica
Option B: Identify the mineral in the blank space of the equation.
Explanation: Explanation: The reaction of orthoclase with carbonic acid yields kaolinite {Al2Si2O5(OH)4 } and Pot. Carbonate and silica.

Question: 7. Which of the following about Spheroidal weathering is not true?
Option A: a) It is a complex type of weathering
Option B: b) Both mechanical and chemical weathering are believed to happen
Option C: c) Formation of joints is involved
Option D: d) Formation of joints is not involved
Explanation: Explanation: Spheroidal weathering is a complex type of weathering observed in jointed rocks and characterized with the breaking of original rock mass into spheroidal blocks. Both mechanical and chemical weathering are believed to actively cooperate in causing spheroidal weathering. The original solid rock mass is split into small block masses by development of parallel joints.

Question: 8. Factor not affecting weathering is
Explanation: Explanation: Weathering is affected by the factors like nature of the rock, climate, physical environment but is not affected by colour of the rock. It has no influence over its weathering.

Question: 9. It is said that Sandstone is more resistant to weathering compared to Granite. What is the basic reason behind this phenomenon?
Option A: a) The external outline form of sandstone
Option B: b) Sandstone is harder than granite
Option C: c) Granite is mainly made of quartz
Option D: d) Sandstone is mainly made of quartz
Explanation: Explanation: Among granite and sandstones exposed to atmosphere simultaneously in the same or adjoining areas having hot and humid climate, the sandstone will resist weathering to a great extent because they are made up mainly of quartz(SiO2) which is highly weathering resistant mineral.

Question: 10. Identify the pair mismatched
Option A: a) Cold and humid – Both mechanical and chemical weathering
Option B: b) Dry and cold – Neither of them
Option C: c) Hot and humid – Mechanical weathering is predominant
Option D: d) Hot and dry – Mechanical weathering is predominant
Explanation: Explanation: In the hot and humid conditions chemical weathering is predominant and not mechanical, since, there is presence of moisture.

Question: 11. Which of the following rock forming minerals is more resistant to weathering compared to Hornblende?
Explanation: Explanation: The resistance to weathering increases in the following order for dark coloured minerals- Olivine, Augite, Hornblende, Biotite. Hence only Biotite is most resistant. Calcite as it is very reactive among the rock forming minerals.

Question: 12. Which of the following is true about Eluvium?
Option A: a) It is that category of end product of weathering that has been moved to some distance after its formation.
Option B: b) It is associated with weathering of slopes
Option C: c) It is the end product of weathering that happens to lie over and above the parent rock
Option D: d) Regolith is not the other name for Eluvium
Explanation: Explanation: The basic definition of Eluvium is “It is the end product of weathering that happens to lie over and above the parent rock”. Regolith is another term for eluvium.

Question: 13. The zone consisting of mixed composition is
Explanation: Explanation: Zone B is of mixed composition, partly of soil and partly of weathered rock, the latter becoming more dominating with depth.

Question: 14. Among the following the term which is not effect of chemical weathering is
Explanation: Explanation: Disfiguring, pitting, honeycombing and loss of surface appearance are quite common effects chemical weathering on stones used irrationally without due regard to the local environment. Scree formation happens due to mechanical weathering.

Question: 1. The winds are formed basically due to which reason?
Explanation: Explanation: Winds are born mainly due to non-uniform heating of the surface of the earth at different places causing differences in atmospheric pressure. The pressure difference so created makes the atmospheric gases (the air) to move from areas of high pressure to areas of low pressure in the form of winds.

Question: 2. The removal of particles of dust and sand by strong winds is called
Explanation: Explanation: The process of removal of dust and sand by strong winds is called deflation. In Latin, ‘deflare’ means ‘to blow away’. It is the main process of wind erosion in desert regions.

Question: 3. The water in an oasis is obtained from which source?
Explanation: Explanation: Sometimes due to deflation, huge depressions are created in the deserts to such an extent that the depression becomes so deep that it intersects with the groundwater table. And it gets partially filled up with water and this is called an oasis.

Question: 4. The type of erosion which involves rubbing, grinding is
Explanation: Explanation: The type of erosion involving rubbing, grinding, abrading and polishing the rock surfaces by any natural agent (wind, water or ice) with the help of its lead while passing over the rocks is termed as abrasion.

Question: 5. Which among the following is called “Mushroom rocks” ?
Explanation: Explanation: Pedestal rocks are also often called mushroom rocks because of their likeness to mushrooms popping up closely in a level land.

Question: 6. The rock which is well polished by wind abrasion is called
Explanation: Explanation: Ventifacts are small sized rock fragments showing one, two or three or even more typically wind-polished surfaces called faces. The polishing of different sides of originally rough fragments is caused by prolonged wind abrasion.

Question: 7. The factor which does not affect the attrition by wind is
Explanation: Explanation: Factors which affect attrition by wind are nature of the region, velocity of wind and duration. It is not affected by sunlight.

Question: 8. Which of the following about saltation is not true?
Option A: a) In this process the heavier and coarse sediments are lifted up
Option B: b) They are lifted up periodically and for short distances
Option C: c) In this process the light-density particles are carried away
Option D: d) It is the process of sediment transport by series of jump
Explanation: Explanation: The heavier and coarse sediments such as sand grains, pebbles and gravels etc. are lifted up periodically during high velocity times and only for short distances and that too for smaller heights above the ground. The uplifting of lighter particles is called suspension.

Question: 10. Which among the following has S-shaped outline?
Explanation: Explanation: A typical sigmoidal dune is characterized with the absence of horns or cusps and a curved outline. In its simplest form, a sigmoidal dune is a steep sided ridge that extends in a sinuous or S-shaped outline.

Question: 11. The type of dune which is short lived is
Explanation: Explanation: Most of the dunes are migratory in nature and among all, Barchans are especially known to move ahead at the rate of 25 to 250 meters a month. Hence barchans are said to be short-lived relative to other dunes.

Question: 12. The particle size in a Loess is around _________
Explanation: Explanation: A typical Loess is unconsolidated, unstratified, and porous accumulation of particles of the size range 0.01-0.05 mm in diameter. This size fraction makes almost 40 percent of a particular loess deposit rest being made up of still finer clay grade material.

Question: 13. What is the term used for wind blown deposits of silt and clay grade particles?
Explanation: Explanation: The term loess is used for wind blown deposits of silt and clay grade particles. Dune is used to refer to sand particles. Ventifacts and hills are usually rocks.

Question: 1. The branch of geology which deals with the morphology, classification, mechanism and causes of development of these rock structures is called as
Explanation: Explanation: The basic definition of structural geology is “the branch of geology which deals with the morphology, classification, mechanism and causes of development of these rock structures”. Hence the answer Structural Geology.

Question: 2. Stratification can be seen widely in which of the following rocks?
Explanation: Explanation: Most sedimentary rocks are deposited under conditions which favour development of distinct layers piled up one above another, from bottom to top. These layers also called beds or strata.

Question: 4. Most widespread rock on earth is
Option D: d) All are in equal quantities
Explanation: Explanation: It is said that sedimentary rocks are superficially the most widespread rocks, forming more than 75% of the exposed surface of the earth.

Question: 5. Which of the following about lamination is not true?
Option A: a) It is closely related to stratification
Option B: b) It is literally paper thin
Option C: c) It is a layered structure developed in extremely fine grained igneous rocks
Option D: d) It is a layered structure developed in extremely fine grained sedimentary rocks
Explanation: Explanation: The term lamination is closely related to stratification. It is a layered structure developed in extremely fine grained sedimentary rocks made up of clay and silt. The layers are paper thin literally speaking.

Question: 6. The maximum angle of inclination of a layer of a rock with the horizontal is
Explanation: Explanation: The definition of dip is “The maximum angle of inclination of a layer of a rock with the horizontal”. It is expressed both in terms of degree of inclination and direction of inclination.

Question: 7. Angle of dip is measured using which instrument?
Explanation: Explanation: The direction of dip is determined with a simple compass whereas the angle of dip is determined with an instrument called clinometer, which comes built in with the compass.

Question: 8. Which among the following is not a type of dip?
Explanation: Explanation: The types of dips are primary, secondary, local and regional. Widespread dip is not considered as a dip.

Question: 9. The term “intrusion” is basically associated with which type of rock?
Option D: d) Not associated with any type of rock
Explanation: Explanation: Igneous rocks are formed from cooling and crystallization of hot molten material called magma/lava depending on the place of occurrence. The magma gets intruded or injected into the pre-existing rocks of any type- called the host rocks and takes variously shaped forms on cooling. These forms are commonly termed as Intrusion.

Question: 10. The dip which involves tectonic forces is
Option D: d) No dip involves tectonic forces
Explanation: Explanation: Secondary dip is the inclination induced in the strata after its deposition due to the tectonic forces to which such strata have been subsequently subjected. Secondary dips may range in value up to vertical.

Question: 11. A coal seam is exposed on a horizontal ground. If it is 30° towards West. Its width of outcrop on a level ground is 360 m. What is its true thickness?
Explanation: Explanation: The equation to calculate True thickness is given byTrue thickness = Width of outcrop * Sin 30°By substitution and calculation, we get 180 m.True thickness = 360 * sin (30°) = 180 m

Question: 12. At a dam site, a bed of sandstone is exposed on horizontal ground. If it is 25° towards East. Its width of outcrop on a level ground is 240 m, what is its vertical thickness?
Explanation: Explanation: Vertical thickness = Width of outcrop * tan (angle of inclination)Vertical thickness = 240 * tan (25°) = 111.91 m

Question: 13. The study of outcrop dimensions doesn’t involve which of the following aspect?
Explanation: Explanation: The study of rock composition and type of rock is not done under the outcrop dimensions whereas the rest are thoroughly studied under the topic.

Question: 14. Foliation is a primary structure of which type of rock?
Option D: d) Not associated with any rock
Explanation: Explanation: Stratification and lamination are the most common primary structures of sedimentary rocks; crystalline structure is typical of igneous rocks and foliation is a typical primary structure of metamorphic rocks.

Question: 15. The dip of a layer measured in the direction that is at right angle to strike is
Explanation: Explanation: When the dip of a layer is measured in a direction that is essentially at right angles to the strike of that particular layer, then it is called true dip. When the dip of a layer is measured in any other direction, which is not at right angles to its strike direction, it is called an apparent dip.

Question: 1. What are the undulations or bends developed in rocks called?
Explanation: Explanation: Folds may be defined as undulations or bends or curvatures developed in the rocks of the crust as a result of stresses to which these rocks have been subjected from time to time in the past history of the Earth.

Question: 2. Folds develop in which type of rock
Explanation: Explanation: The folds may develop in any type of rock and may be of any shape and flexures.

Question: 3. Which type of deformation is folding?
Explanation: Explanation: In general, folding is a ductile type of deformation experienced by the rocks compared to the brittle deformation where the rocks actually get broken and displaced when stressed.

Question: 4. Folding is ________ process
Explanation: Explanation: Folding is a very slow geological process and indicates an effort of the rocks in a particular environment to adjust themselves to the changing force fields operating on, within or around them.

Question: 5. Which among the following is not a part of fold?
Explanation: Explanation: Parts of a fold include, limbs, hinge, axis of a fold, plunge of a fold and crest & trough. Height of fold is not referred as its part.

Question: 6. The minimum number of limbs for a fold are
Explanation: Explanation: An individual fold will have a minimum of two limbs but when the folds occur in groups, as this is common, a middle limb will be common to two adjacent folds.

Question: 7. The point where the curvature is maximum is ________
Explanation: Explanation: In a folded layer, a point can be found where curvature is maximum and one limb ends and the other limb starts from that point. This is the hinge point.

Question: 8. When the plunge said to be zero, then the axis of the fold is said to be
Option C: c) Inclined at 60° to the horizontal
Option D: d) Inclined at 60° to its normal.
Explanation: Explanation: Axis is a line and plunge is the angle which the line makes with a horizontal. A fold having a horizontal axis will obviously have a zero plunge.

Question: 10. What is axis of a fold?
Option A: a) Line drawn normal to the hinge line
Option B: b) Line drawn at 60° to hinge line
Option C: c) Line drawn parallel to hinge line
Option D: d) Line which doesn’t pass through hinge line.
Explanation: Explanation: Axis of fold is defined as a line drawn parallel to the hinge line of a fold. In other words, line representing the intersection of the axial plane of a fold with any bed of the fold.

Question: 11. How is the plunge of a fold measured?
Explanation: Explanation: The plunge is measured like dip of a bedding plane, both in terms of direction of plunge and degree of plunge.

Question: 13. Identify the part labelled  “A” in the below figure.
Explanation: Explanation: Limbs are the sides or flanks of a fold. The part labelled “A” in the figure is a limb of fold.

Question: 14. Which of the following about axial plane is not true.
Option B: b) Axial plane may be vertical, inclined or horizontal
Option C: c) Axial plane may be planar or non-planar
Option D: d) Axial plane need not pass through all points of maximum curvature in a folded sequence
Explanation: Explanation: An axial plane is defined as imaginary plane that passes through all the points of maximum curvature in a folded sequence. It may be vertical, inclined or horizontal. Also it can be either planar or non-planar.

Question: 1. The type of fold in which the limbs dip away from each other at the crest is
Explanation: Explanation: Anticlines are defined as those folds in which the limbs dip away from each other at the crest in the simplest forms.

Question: 2. The fold which is convex downwards is
Explanation: Explanation: Synclines are the reverse of anticlines in all details and the strata are downarched, that is, these become convex downwards.

Question: 3. Which of the following is not true about Anticline?
Option B: b) Geologically older rocks occupy a position in the interior of the fold
Option C: c) The limbs dip away from each other at the crest
Explanation: Explanation: Anticlines are said to convex upwards and not downwards. Synclines are convex downwards.

Question: 4. What is the other name for upright fold?
Explanation: Explanation: Symmetrical folds are also called normal folds or upright folds. In such a fold, the axial plane is essentially vertical.

Question: 5. Fold in which the limbs lie exactly one over another
Explanation: Explanation: In recumbent folds, one limb comes to lie exactly under the other limb so that a drill hole dug at the surface in the upper limb passes through the lower limb also.

Question: 6. Which of the following is also an overturned fold?
Explanation: Explanation: Recumbent folds are described as extreme types of overturned folds in which the axial plane acquires an almost horizontal attitude.

Question: 7. Fold with flattened top is
Explanation: Explanation: Box fold may be described as a special type of fold with exceptionally flattened top and steep inclined limbs almost forming three sides of a rectangle.

Question: 8. The type of fold in which fold angle is between 10° to 90°
Explanation: Explanation: When it comes to fold angle as the basis of classification, the fold with fold angle between 10° and 90° is called tight fold.

Question: 9. Which of among the following is not a type of fold based on behaviour with depth?
Explanation: Explanation: The first three options are the types based on behaviour with depth where asymmetric fold is based on position of axial plane.

Question: 11. Where can folds be observed in the southern part of India?
Option D: d) Cannot be observed in southern India
Explanation: Explanation: Among the peninsular mountains, only the Vindhyan and the Satpuran ranges show folding in a prominent manner. .

Question: 12. Where is the Liddar Valley Anticline situated?
Explanation: Explanation: The Liddar Valley Anticline in Kashmir Himalayas is often represented as a classic example in that almost complete sequence of Palaeozoic Era is fully developed in this anticline.

Question: 1. Pick the wrong statement about recumbent fold
Option A: a) It has the arch, which is zone of curvature
Option B: b) It has the shell, which is the inner zone, made up of mostly igneous rocks
Option C: c) It has the shell, which is the outer zone, made up of mostly sedimentary rocks
Option D: d) It has the core, which is the innermost zone, maybe made up of igneous rocks and metamorphic rocks
Explanation: Explanation: The shell part of a recumbent, which is the outer zone, is mostly made up of sedimentary rocks. Hence the second statement is wrong regarding it.

Question: 2. The type of fold which is actually a group of folds is
Explanation: Explanation: Isoclinal folds are group of folds in which all the axial planes are essentially parallel, meaning that all the component limbs are at equal amounts.

Question: 4. In which class of folds, the Isogans converge inwards?
Explanation: Explanation: Determination of dips may be made and then lines of equal dips are drawn. These are called Isogans. In Class 1 folds, the Isogans converge inwards.

Question: 6. Which is the type of fold with similar degree of folding for indefinite depths?
Explanation: Explanation: Similar folds are the folds in which degree of folding is observed to be similar for indefinite depths.

Question: 8. Gentle folds have fold angle between
Option D: d) They don’t belong to this type
Explanation: Explanation: For the classification of folds on the basis of fold angle, a fold is said to be gentle fold if the fold angle is between 170° to 180°.

Question: 9. Which is the class of fold with the degree of curvature greater on the outer arc compared to the inner arc?
Explanation: Explanation: Class 3 folds are just the reverse of class 1 folds; in these folds, the degree of curvature as measured on the outer arc is greater than that of the inner arc.

Question: 10. The fold which is associated with the formation of mountains is
Explanation: Explanation: Great importance is attached to the major depressions, the geosynclines, in the process of mountain building.

Question: 11. The anticlines signifying larger bending are called
Explanation: Explanation: The anticlines which signify larger bending and uplifting of strata on sub-continental scales is expressed by the term Geanticlines.

Question: 12. The folds caused due to the drag effect are
Explanation: Explanation: Drag folds derive their name from cause of origin; they develop due to drag effect suffered by the soft and ductile type material of the incompetent rock.

Question: 1. How many types of folds are there with plunge as basis?
Explanation: Explanation: Only two main types are recognized as the types of folds on the basis plunge.

Question: 2. What is a plunging fold?
Option A: a) Fold with fold axis horizontal
Option B: b) Fold with fold axis only vertical
Option C: c) Fold with fold axis not horizontal
Option D: d) This is not a type of fold
Explanation: Explanation: Any fold in which fold axis is not horizontal, that is, it makes an angle with the horizontal, may be described as a plunging fold.

Question: 3. A fold in which the folding continues in the direction of the axis of the fold is
Explanation: Explanation: Any fold in which the axis of the fold is essentially horizontal, that is, the plunging continues indefinitely in the direction of the axis of the fold is specifically described as non-plunging fold.

Question: 4. A fold which is not based on profile of the folded strata is
Explanation: Explanation: Cheveron fold, conjugate fold, cuspate fold are the types of fold based on profile of the fold surface whereas, plunging fold is based on plunge of the fold.

Question: 5. Folds with two hinges and three planar limbs are called
Explanation: Explanation: Conjugate folds are composite folds characterised with two hinges and three planar limbs in which the central limb is exceptionally flattened.

Question: 6. Folds characterized by well-defined, sharp hinge points are called
Explanation: Explanation: Cheveron folds are the folds characterised with well-defined, sharp hinge points and straight planar limbs.

Question: 7. Pick the non-planar fold from the following.
Explanation: Explanation: The limbs of the cuspate fields are not planar, they are quite clearly curved becoming concave upwards in the case of anticlines and concave downwards in the case of synclines.

Question: 8. Which of the following is not true about cylindrical folds?
Option A: a) They resemble sections of pipes
Option B: b) They have very well defined axes of folds
Option C: c) These well defined axes are repeated parallel to each other
Option D: d) These well defined axes are not repeated parallel to each other
Explanation: Explanation: Folds in which repetition of axes parallel to themselves is not possible , are classified as non-cylindrical. The first three statements are true about the cylindrical folds.

Question: 11. Folds which mostly occur in groups are based on
Option A: a) Profile of the fold surface
Explanation: Explanation: Folds which are based on mode of occurrence, rarely occur singularly; more often they occur in groups.

Question: 12. Which of the following about drag fold is not true?
Option A: a) The axes of the drag folds are parallel to those of the major folds
Option B: b) The drag folds plunge in the same manner as the major folds
Option C: c) The layers on the upper side of the drag folds slide away from the synclinal axis
Option D: d) The axes of the drag folds are not parallel to those of the major folds
Explanation: Explanation: It has been established that the drag folds are parallel to those of the major folds. Hence the last option is wrong. The second and the third also true about drag folds.

Question: 1. What is Orogeny?
Explanation: Explanation: The geosynclines serve as depositional fields to which sediments are derived by the erosion of adjoining geanticlines and the sediments get accumulated and compacted. This material is then compressed and uplifted in the second stage of orogeny, which is the mountain building activity, to gradually take the shape of mountain systems.

Question: 2. The fold associated with magmatic activity is
Explanation: Explanation: Diapiric folds are anticlines or domes in which uparching of strata isattributed to the rising of viscous magma from below.

Question: 3. A group of strata centrally centrally uplifted is
Explanation: Explanation: Domes are a group of strata centrally uplifted in such a way that seen from the top, these dip away in all directions.

Question: 4. Pick the incorrect statement about basins.
Option A: a) Basins are the reverse of the domes
Option B: b) They are group of strata that are centrally depressed
Option C: c) Group of strata that are centrally uplifted
Option D: d) Involved layers dip towards a common central point from all sides
Explanation: Explanation: Basins are a group of strata that are centrally depressed in such a way that the involved layers dip towards a common central point from all the sides.

Question: 5. Which among the following is considered as compound anticline?
Explanation: Explanation: In any two cross sections drawn mutually at right angles to each other in a dome, a fold of anticlinal character will be seen to emerge. As such, a dome may be considered as a compound anticline.

Question: 6. Which is the fold depicting localized warping?
Explanation: Explanation: A monocline is described as essentially a localized warping in which case otherwise horizontal strata show a single bend for a limited length and attain the horizontal attitude once again.

Question: 7. The fold which actually is just strata dipping in some direction
Explanation: Explanation: A homocline actually describes a sequence of strata dipping in the same general direction at a uniform angle, especially when such structure is established to be a limb of major fold.

Question: 9. The folds which develop within body of weaker rocks are
Explanation: Explanation: Drag folds may be defined as minor folds developed within the body of incompetent or weaker rocks surrounded on both sides by layers of competent or stronger rocks.

Question: 12. What would the two cross sections drawn at mutually right angle directions in a basin show?
Explanation: Explanation: Unlike domes, two cross sections drawn at mutually right angle directions in a basin show clearly synclinal characters. Hence a basin may be called a compound syncline.

Question: 1. Pick the option which is not the cause of folding.
Option A: a) Folding due to tangential tension
Option B: b) Folding due to tangential compression
Option D: d) Folding due to differential compression
Explanation: Explanation: The various causes of folding that are studied are, folding due to- tangential compression, intrusions and differential compression. Hence first option is not correct.

Question: 2. Bending or warping is studied under
Explanation: Explanation: Folding may be either due to tectonic causes or due to non-tectonic causes. The tectonic folding of the rocks is bending or warping of rocks due very conspicuously to superficial processes.

Question: 3. The cause of folding which does not occur due to the tangential stresses is
Explanation: Explanation: Under the influence of tangential stresses, folding may develop in either of the three ways: flexural folding, flowage folding and shear folding.

Question: 4. How does the thickness of the layer affect flexural folding?
Option A: a) Thinner the layers, greater is the slip
Option B: b) Thicker the layers, lesser is the slip
Option C: c) Thicker the layers, greater is the slip
Explanation: Explanation: Thickness of the layers and nature of the contact are important factors on which the amount of slip depends. Thicker the layer, greater is the slip.

Question: 5. Which are the rocks more prone to flexural slip?
Explanation: Explanation: Types of the rocks involved: siltstones, sandstones and limestones are more prone to flexure slip folding compared to soft clays and shales.

Question: 6. In which cause of folding, the thickness of fold does not remain uniform?
Explanation: Explanation: During the compression due to flowage folding, the material of the involved layers behaves almost as a viscous or plastic mass and gets buckled up and deformed at varying rates suffering unequal distortion. In such cases the thickness of the resulting fold does not remain uniform.

Question: 7. Flowage folding occurs in which type of rocks
Explanation: Explanation: Flowage folding is the principal process of folding in incompetent or weaker, plastic type of rocks such as clays, shales, gypsum and rock salt etc.

Question: 8. How does the distance from hinge point affect displacement due to folding?
Option A: a) Greater the distance, larger is the displacement
Option B: b) Lesser the distance, larger is the displacement
Option C: c) Doesn’t depend on the distance from hinge point
Option D: d) Greater the distance, smaller is the displacement
Explanation: Explanation: Distance from hinge point is also an important factor on which displacement of folding depends. Greater the distance from the hinge points, larger is the displacement.

Question: 10. The process of folding which causes fracture in rocks initially is
Explanation: Explanation: In many cases, folding is attributed to shearing stresses rather than simple compression. It is assumed that in such a process, numerous closely spaced fractures develop in the rock at the first stage of the process.

Question: 11. Pick the wrong statement. The converging plates may be
Option B: b) A continental plate and an oceanic plate
Option C: c) A continental plate and an island plate
Explanation: Explanation: The converging plates may be- two continental plates, a continental plate and an oceanic plate or a continental plate and an island plate but not two oceanic plate.

Question: 1. Which rock is lifted up during the folding due to intrusions?
Explanation: Explanation: In magmatic intrusions, highly viscous magma may be forced up gradually and with considerable force so that sedimentary host rocks overlying are lifted up to provide the space for the rising magma.

Question: 2. The process of folding which is considered to be non-tectonic is
Explanation: Explanation: Folding due to differential compression is totally dependent on the load from above and are attributed to superficial causes. These are, therefore, non-tectonic folds.

Question: 3. What is the indirect cause for warping or folding?
Explanation: Explanation: If the strata in question is not homogenous, the bending may not be uniform in character and results in warping or folding of different types.

Question: 4. What is the reason for rock bursts?
Option A: a) Change in attitude of rocks
Explanation: Explanation: All the stresses that have acted on the rocks during their folding are generally absorbed by these rocks by undergoing strain. Enough stored energy is released as soon as the excavations are made and this leads to rock bursts.

Question: 5. What is affected when the layers of undesirable nature are encountered?
Option D: d) All the three are affected
Explanation: Explanation: Same layers may be repeated along an alignment or one or more encountered layers are of undesirable nature, the project cost may be affected as also the time schedule and safety of the project.

Question: 7. Shattering makes the rocks
Explanation: Explanation: Shattering effect is of utmost importance because shattered rocks become: weak in strength parameters of all types; porous and pervious in character.

Question: 9. The process of folding which mainly causes uparching is
Option A: a) Folding due to differential compression
Option B: b) Folding due to tangential shearing
Option D: d) Folding due to differential tension
Explanation: Explanation: Intrusion of magma or even rock salt bodies from beneath has been found to be the cause of uparching of the overlying strata.

Question: 10. What is the cause for downward bending?
Explanation: Explanation: Strata that are being compacted under load in a basin of sedimentation develop, with passage of time, downward bending especially in the zones of maximum loading.

Question: 11. Which rock might undergo flowage folding?
Explanation: Explanation: Flowage folding is the principal process of folding in incompetent or weaker, plastic type of rocks such as clays, shales, gypsum and rock salt etc.

Question: 12. At what angle is the primary lateral compressive force said to act in tangential compression?
Option A: a) 60° to the trend of the folds
Option B: b) 90° to the trend of the folds
Option C: c) 30° to the trend of the folds
Option D: d) 45° to the trend of the folds
Explanation: Explanation: In general, the primary lateral compressive force is believed to act at right angles to the trend of the folds.

Question: 1. What are the fractures along which there has been relative movement of blocks called?
Explanation: Explanation: The definition of faults is “Those fractures along which there has been relative movement of the blocks past each other”. The entire process of development of fractures and displacement of the blocks against each other is termed as faulting.

Question: 2. What is the key word in the definition of fault?
Explanation: Explanation: The key words in the definition are fracture and movement. The exact significance of these key words must be clearly understood.

Question: 4. Faulting is a _________ process.
Explanation: Explanation: Faulting is a major tectonic process of great geological importance. The geological history of the Earth bears innumerable events recording in the script of folding, faulting and jointing.

Question: 5. In which direction does displacement of blocks happen?
Explanation: Explanation: The displacement of blocks created in the rock due to faulting may take place in any direction: parallel to the fault surface; in an inclined manner or even rotational.

Question: 6. What is the angle that can be made by fault plane with the horizontal?
Explanation: Explanation: Fault planes may be vertical, horizontal or inclined at any angle with the horizontal.

Question: 7. What is the planar surface of fracture along which relative displacement of bodies has taken place called?
Explanation: Explanation: Fault plane is the planar surface of fracture along which relative displacement of the blocks takes place during the process of faulting. When it is not planar, the same surface is simply described as fault surface.

Question: 8. What is the angle of fault plane with the horizontal called?
Explanation: Explanation: The dip of the fault is its inclination with the horizontal as measured in a vertical plane at right angles to the strike of the fault.

Question: 9. Parameter(s) considered for dip is
Explanation: Explanation: The dip is measured both in terms of direction of dip as well as angle of dip just as in the bedding plane of strata.

Question: 10. What is hade?
Option A: a) Inclination of fault with horizontal
Option B: b) Inclination of fault with vertical
Option C: c) Inclination of fault with any strata
Option D: d) Bearing of the fault with ground
Explanation: Explanation: The hade of the fault is the angle which the fault makes with the vertical. In other words it is the complimentary to the dip angle.

Question: 11. What is the bearing of a line of intersection of fault plane and horizontal called?
Explanation: Explanation: The strike of the fault is the bearing or geographical direction of a line obtained by intersection of a horizontal plane with the fault plane.

Question: 1. A fault has how many walls?
Explanation: Explanation: In faults, the concept of walls is very important and must be understood very clearly. In a rock body, when a fracture takes place, it divided the rock into two parts or two blocks.

Question: 3. What is the block which suffer displacement in faulting called?
Explanation: Explanation: The blocks which suffer displacement and stand on either sides of the fracture are called as walls. Generally there exist two types of walls, hanging wall and foot wall.

Question: 5. Who coined the terms “hanging wall” and “foot wall”?
Explanation: Explanation: Actually the terms “hanging wall” and “foot wall” have been coined by the miners: while traversing along a track excavated in fault plane, the wall under their feet would be foot wall whereas the other block would hang above their heads.

Question: 6. What is a small region with definite thickness and distinct composition having numerous closely placed parallel fractures called?
Explanation: Explanation: Fault zone is a small region with definite thickness and distinct composition having numerous closely placed parallel fractures within itself along which there have been clear displacements.

Question: 7. What is the nature of displacement in shear zone?
Explanation: Explanation: The displacements in shear zones are generally ductile in nature compared to brittle fracturing in simple faults or fault zones.

Question: 9. Slip is expressed in terms of
Explanation: Explanation: The slip is defined as a relative displacement of any points that were formerly contiguous to each other, as measured along the fault plane. It may be expressed in millimetres, metres or even kilometres.

Question: 10. The type of slip not considered for study is
Explanation: Explanation: The slip is further distinguished on the basis of direction of displacement with respect to the fault as dip-slip, strike-slip or oblique slip. Hade slip is not one such.

Question: 11. What is the vertical component of dip separation called?
Explanation: Explanation: Throw is the vertical component of the dip separation measured in the direction perpendicular to the strike of the fault in a vertical plane.

Question: 1. Heave is _______
Option A: a) Horizontal component of dip separation
Option B: b) Vertical component of dip separation
Option D: d) Signifying separation between two beds
Explanation: Explanation: Heave is the horizontal component of dip separation measured in a direction perpendicular to the strike of the fault in a vertical plane.

Question: 2. What signifies actual separation between two beds?
Explanation: Explanation: Stratigraphic throw signifies actual separation between two beds with known stratigraphical position in a sequence of rocks that are now brought into contact by faulting.

Question: 3. What is the term related to slickensides and used to express angular relationship?
Explanation: Explanation: Rake is a term related to slickensides in faults. It is used to express the angular relationship of slickensides or some other line with the fault plane.

Question: 4. Pick the term which is not a crushed material.
Explanation: Explanation: Rubbing and mutual shearing of blocks during faulting, especially in brittle rocks, often produces typical crushed materials from the involved blocks that are useful indicators of faulting in that region. The most common and important products are: Gouge, Fault breccia and Mylonite.

Question: 5. What is also called as Micro breccia?
Explanation: Explanation: Mylonite is also called as micro-breccia and is similar to fault breccia but contains very fine-grained broken particles from the involved rocks that get thoroughly cemented and compacted.

Question: 6. The finely pulverized, clay-like powdered rock material is
Explanation: Explanation: Gouge is finely pulverized, clay-like powdered rock material, which occurs at or near the base of the faulted zones.

Question: 11. Identify the region marked as “OP2”.
Explanation: Explanation: Heave is the horizontal component of dip separation measured in a direction perpendicular to the strike of the fault in a vertical plane.

Question: 1. Which type of classification emphasises on appearance?
Option A: a) Based on direction of slip
Option C: c) Based on mode of occurrence
Option D: d) Based on amount of dip of the fault
Explanation: Explanation: The emphasis in the case of faults based on apparent movement as basis is only on appearance because actually it may require to be established which of the two parts, hanging wall and the foot wall, has moved during faulting and by how much.

Question: 2. Type of fault not considered under apparent movement as basis is
Explanation: Explanation: The various faults under apparent movement as basis are, normal faults, reverse faults, hinge faults and strike-slip faults. Strike faults is not studied under this basis.

Question: 3. Fault in which hanging wall has apparently moved down with respect to foot wall is
Explanation: Explanation: Normal fault is a fault in which hanging wall has apparently moved down with respect to foot wall.

Question: 4. What do the normal faults cause to the crust of the Earth?
Explanation: Explanation: Due to the inclines nature of the fault plane and downward displacement of a part of the strata, normal faults cause an extension in the crust wherever they occur.

Question: 6. Most common angle of normal faults is
Explanation: Explanation: In normal faults, the fault plane may be inclines at any angle between horizontal and vertical, but most commonly, the fault angles are between 45° and vertical.

Question: 7. What is the other name for normal faults?
Explanation: Explanation: Normal faults are also often termed as gravity faults especially when it is established that the hanging wall has actually moved down with respect to the foot wall.

Question: 8. Alps in an example of which type of fault?
Explanation: Explanation: Numerous small and big examples of horsts are found in major mountain systems such as Alps, Central Europe and East Africa.

Question: 9. Horst and graben are physiographic features of which type of faults?
Explanation: Explanation: Horst and graben are the physiographic features caused by normal faults occurring in pairs.

Question: 10. The type of fault which appears in such a way that the central wedge appears raised high up with respect to the sides is
Explanation: Explanation: When two normal faults appear on either side of a central wedge shaped elongated block in such a way that the central wedge appears raised high up with respect to the sides, the outstanding structure is called a horst.

Question: 11. Block mountains are caused by which type of faults?
Explanation: Explanation: Sometimes the horsts may be high and extensive enough to be called a Block mountain. In many horsts, the border faults are almost parallel in strike and very high angled.

Question: 12. Which fault is the reverse of horst?
Explanation: Explanation: Graben is almost the reverse of a horst in structure and appearance. A graben may be described as an elongated wedge shaped central block, which appears to have moved downward with respect to the side blocks along two downward converging normal faults.

Question: 1. Horsts and grabens are believed to occur due to
Explanation: Explanation: The origin of horsts and grabens is believed to be due to lateral tension in the crust in most cases.

Question: 2. Faults involving extensive blocks and resulting in horsts and grabens are called
Explanation: Explanation: Faults involving extensive blocks and resulting in horsts and grabens are often called as block faults and the process as block faulting.

Question: 3. Faults in which the fault plane is vertical and the resulting movement is vertical is
Explanation: Explanation: Faults in which the fault plane is vertical or nearly so and the resulting movement of blocks is also in a vertical direction are termed as vertical faults. It is customary to group vertical faults along with normal faults while discussing their origin.

Question: 4. In which fault the hanging wall appears to have moved up with respect to the foot wall?
Explanation: Explanation: Reverse fault is such a type of fault in which the hanging wall appears to have moved up with respect to the foot wall.

Question: 5. The fault in which the fault plane is generally inclined between 45° and horizontal is
Explanation: Explanation: In reverse faults, the fault plane is generally inclined between horizontal and 45 degrees although reverse faults with steeply inclined fault surfaces have been also encountered.

Question: 6. What does the reverse fault cause to the crust of the Earth?
Explanation: Explanation: By virtue of their inclination and direction of movement, reverse faulting involves shortening of the crust of the crust of the Earth (compared with normal faults).

Question: 7. Thrust faults belong to which variety of faults?
Explanation: Explanation: Thrust faults are, broadly speaking, such varieties of reverse faults in which the hanging wall has moved up relative to the foot wall.

Question: 8. What is the fault angle of the thrust faults?
Explanation: Explanation: Thrust faults are the types of reverse faults in which the hanging wall has moved up relative to the foot wall and the faults dip at angles below 45 degrees. Faults dipping above 45 degrees with hanging wall having gone up are then called as reverse faults.

Question: 9. The type of thrust in which the hanging wall seems to have been actively and actually displaced with respect to a passive foot wall is called
Explanation: Explanation: Thrusts are further distinguished into two sub-types: The over thrusts and the under thrusts. In the over thrusts, the hanging wall seems to have been actively and actually displaced with respect to a passive foot wall.

Question: 10. Which mountain range presents example of thrust faults?
Explanation: Explanation: The Himalayan Mountains in the Indian sub-continent present numerous examples of thrust faults developed all along its extension from northwest to southeast.

Question: 11. What is the term used for blocks or rocks that have been translated to great distances?
Explanation: Explanation: Nappes is the term used for extensive blocks of rocks that have been translated to great distances, often ranging to several kilometres, along a thrust plane.

Question: 12. The term which studied under faults but also is associated with folding is
Explanation: Explanation: The large-scale movement of nappes may be attributed to a major thrusting or a recumbent folding followed by thrust faulting.

Question: 1. The phenomenon not associated with imbricate structures is
Option A: a) Series of thrust blocks occur in close proximity
Option B: b) Thrust blocks are piled up one above another
Option C: c) All fault surfaces dip in the same direction
Option D: d) Thrust blocks aren’t piled up one above another
Explanation: Explanation: When a series of thrust faults occur in close proximity, thrust blocks are piled up one above another and all the fault surfaces dip in same direction. The resulting interesting structure is known as an imbricate structure.

Question: 3. Most common term used for strike-slip faults is
Explanation: Explanation: There are some other terms used for strike slip faults such as lateral faults, transverse faults, wrench faults and transform faults. Of these, the transform faults are very common and denote strike slip faults specially developed in oceanic ridges.

Question: 4. The type of fault where the faulted blocks have been moved against each other in horizontal direction is
Explanation: Explanation: Strike-slip faults are defined as the faults in which faulted blocks have been moved against each other in an essentially horizontal direction. The fault plane is almost vertical and net slip may be measured in great distances.

Question: 6. San Andres fault is the best example of which type of fault?
Explanation: Explanation: The best example of a strike-slip fault is the great San Andres fault of California. It extends for almost about 1000 km in a NW-SE direction.

Question: 8. If the left block appears to have moved towards the observer, then which type of fault does it belong to?
Explanation: Explanation: Strike-slip faults are further distinguished into right handed or left handed depending on the direction of movement of the block with respect to an observer: it is a left-handed fault if the left block appears to have moved towards the observer and a right handed fault if the right block seems to have moved towards the observer.

Question: 9. What are pivotal faults called as?
Explanation: Explanation: Hinge faults are also called as pivotal or rotational faults. A hinge fault is characterised by a movement of the disrupted blocks along a medial point called the hinge point.

Question: 10. The movement of blocks in hinge faults is
Explanation: Explanation: The movement in hinge fault, is rotational rather translational.

Question: 11. Which is the rare type of fault?
Explanation: Explanation: In hinge faults, the amount of displacement increases away from the hinge point. These are rather rare type of faults.

Question: 12. What is the displacement range of strata in San Andres fault?
Explanation: Explanation: The strata is believed to have suffered displacement varying between 50 km to 200 km in the San Andres fault in California.

Question: 1. The fault not belonging to the classification of fault with attitude of fault as basis
Explanation: Explanation: The mutual relationship of attitude of fault and of the disrupted rock has also been used in some cases for classifying faults into three types: dip faults, strike faults and oblique faults.

Question: 2. Faults that are developed along bedding planes are
Explanation: Explanation: Sometimes he faults are developed along the bedding planes; in such cases they are aptly called bedding faults.

Question: 3. The fault where fault strike is parallel to the dip of the layers broken and disrupted by the fault
Explanation: Explanation: Dip faults are the faults which develop parallel to the dip of the strata. In other words, the fault strike is parallel to the dip of the layers broken and disrupted by the fault.

Question: 4. The fault which is also called as diagonal fault is
Explanation: Explanation: Oblique faults are sometimes called diagonal faults. In such a fault, the fault strike makes an oblique angle with the strike of the rocks in which it has caused the displacement.

Question: 5. The type of fault which is observed in both continental and oceanic environment is
Explanation: Explanation: Strike-slip faults are the most important and widely developed faults in the crust of the earth, which have been observed both on the continental and oceanic environments.

Question: 6. Which is the type of strike-slip fault in which the fault plane has developed transverse to the regional structure?
Explanation: Explanation: Wrench fault is a strike slip fault in origin in which the fault plane has developed transverse to the regional structure and even the net slip has taken place in the same manner.

Question: 7. Transverse fault is the other name for __________ fault.
Explanation: Explanation: The dip of the wrench fault is very steep nearly vertical. These are also sometimes referred as transverse faults.

Question: 8. Where do the transform faults occur extensively?
Explanation: Explanation: Transform faults are strike-slip faults occurring in oceanic ridges on an extensive scale.

Question: 9. Identify the group of small sized faults from the following.
Explanation: Explanation: Enechelon faults may be defined as a group of small sized faults that overlap each other in the region of their occurrence. A second fault appears on the surface at a distance before the first fault ends and so on.

Question: 10. Group of faults which appear emerging outward from a common central region are called
Explanation: Explanation: A group faults that appear emerging outward from a common central region are classified as radial faults. The area is divided into blocks with inwardly tapering ends.

Question: 12. The type of fault not belonging to the classification based on the mode of occurrence is
Explanation: Explanation: Wrench fault is classification with slip as basis whereas, parallel fault, peripheral fault, enechelon fault are based on the mode of occurrence.

Question: 1. What is the effect of faulting on outcrop?
Option A: a) Changes in the elevation of the ground
Option B: b) Omission of some strata where they are normally expected
Option C: c) Repetition of some strata in a given direction
Option D: d) Changes in elevation, omission of some strata, repetition of some strata
Explanation: Explanation: Faulting is essentially a process of rupturing and displacement along the plane of rupture. Its effects may involve- changes in the elevation of the ground, omission of some strata where they are normally expected, repetition of some strata in a given direction and displacements and shifts in the continuity of the same rocks in certain regions.

Question: 2. What is the effect of strike faults to the strata?
Explanation: Explanation: Strike faults are those, which are developed parallel to the strike of the outcrops. These faults produce, besides other changes, two pronounced effects on the outcrops repetition and omission of strata.

Question: 3. When the downthrow is against direction of the bed, it leads to
Explanation: Explanation: Repetition of the strata occurs, when the downthrow is against the direction of the dip of the bed in which faulting has taken place.

Question: 4. When the downthrow is _____________ direction of the dip, it leads to omission.
Explanation: Explanation: Omission of the strata takes place in a strike fault when the downthrow is parallel to the direction of slip of the faulted bed.

Question: 5. What has to be studied at first to tell about the effects with certainty?
Explanation: Explanation: It is only after the study of geological maps that existence of faults at the first place and their effects on the rocks may get established with some certainty.

Question: 6. Dip fault leads to
Explanation: Explanation: In dip faults which occur parallel to the dip of the outcrop, the most prominent effect observed after faulting and erosion of the upthrown block is horizontal shift between the two parts of the outcrop.

Question: 7. Which fault causes offset?
Explanation: Explanation: Oblique faults cause an offset in the sequence, which is associated with either a gap or an overlap depending upon the downthrow direction.

Question: 8. Gap or overlap depends upon
Explanation: Explanation: Oblique faults cause an offset in the sequence, which is associated with either a gap or an overlap depending upon the downthrow direction.

Question: 9. What will result in an offset with overlap?
Explanation: Explanation: Oblique faults with downthrow to the left side result in an offset with an overlap.

Question: 10. What will result in an offset with gap?
Explanation: Explanation: Oblique faults with downthrow to the right side result in an offset with a gap.

Question: 12. What is the effect of faults on topography?
Explanation: Explanation: One of the main effects of the faults on topography is that they very often result in the development of distinct types of steep slopes which are aptly called fault scarps.

Question: 13. The type of scarps not considered under study is
Explanation: Explanation: Three types of fault associated scarps are often recognized: fault scarps, fault-line scarps and composite-fault scarps.

Question: 14. The fault which is result of both fault scarps and fault-line scarps is
Explanation: Explanation: When a given slope is believed is believed to be the result of both of these processes, fault scarp and fault-line scarp, the scarp is of composite type, and is called composite-fault scarp.

Question: 15. The type of scarp involving erosion is
Explanation: Explanation: In the fault-line scarp, the relief is produced due to process of unequal erosion along the fault line with the passage of time.

Question: 1. What is the criteria for a covered surface to be said a fault?
Option D: d) Polished surface, grooves and striations
Explanation: Explanation: An exposed or covered surface may be suspected of being a faulted surface if it polished, and carries grooves and striations.

Question: 2. What is the reason for abrupt termination?
Option A: a) Breaking of strata into blocks
Option B: b) Movement of the disrupted blocks away from each other
Option C: c) Breaking of strata into blocks and movement of disrupted blocks away from each other
Option D: d) Movement of the disrupted blocks towards each other
Explanation: Explanation: A group of beds or some veins or dykes may abruptly terminate along a surface in a given region. This may generally be due to breaking of the strata into blocks and movement of the disrupted blocks away from each other.

Question: 3. What is indicative of faulting?
Explanation: Explanation: When in the field the same layer or rock is encountered more than once in a certain section, that is, it is repeated in space, faulting is indicated. Similarly, omission of certain of beds in some directions as proved by thorough study of stratigraphy of the region, is also indicative of faulting.

Question: 4. Disruption of beds due to faulting results in their
Explanation: Explanation: Disruption of the beds due to faulting generally results in their displacement, which may be determined in terms of slip, separation, offset and gap etc.

Question: 5. What kind of evidence the physiographic features provide?
Explanation: Explanation: Some physiographic features may serve as indirect evidence of faults. Among them, the most important are: aligned springs and offset streams.

Question: 6. The important physiographic evidence studied is
Option D: d) Offset stream and aligned spring
Explanation: Explanation: Some physiographic features may serve as indirect evidence of faults. Among them, the most important are: aligned springs and offset streams.

Question: 7. The resistance to stresses of rocks depend upon
Option C: c) Cohesive strength and internal friction
Explanation: Explanation: Any rock on or below the crust may withstand all the operating stresses up to a limit, which depends upon its cohesive strength and internal friction.

Question: 8. When are the normal stresses formed?
Option C: c) Maximum stress is inclined at certain angle other than right angle
Explanation: Explanation: In highly oversimplified situation, the type of fault likely to form is related to stress field operating in a given area. Thus, talking in terms of the three principal stresses, normal faults would form when, the maximum stress is vertical.

Question: 9. What is the assumed nature of the rock for the study?
Explanation: Explanation: aExplanation: In all the idealized situations, it is assumed that the rocks are isotropic in character and the Mohr-Coulomb Law of rock failure holds good in those cases.

Question: 10. What is the cause for compressive force?
Explanation: Explanation: Gravity or normal faults are believed to be causes under the influence of horizontal tension whereas thrust faults are the result of compressive forces that may throw the rocks into severe type of folding before actual development of faults.

Question: 1. What kind of joints do the faulted rocks form?
Explanation: Explanation: The faulted rocks will form weak foundations and abutments for dam, despite the fact that originally they might have been strong and impervious.

Question: 2. When do the faulted and shear zones become potential areas of further slip and slides?
Explanation: Explanation: Once the fault zones, shear zones or fault surfaces become lubricated with water, they become potential areas for further slips and slides. They may create critical conditions.

Question: 3. Where should a site for a civil engineering project be located?
Option D: d) Must be avoided to possible extent to be built on all three.
Explanation: Explanation: As far as possible the location of a civil engineering project must be avoided on a fault or a fold or a joint. But when there is no other choice, the same location can be treated with necessary methods and then the project can be implemented.

Question: 4. What is not considered about the shear zones?
Explanation: Explanation: The number, size and inclination of the shear zones should be given top consideration.

Question: 5. Bhakra dam in India showed which occurrence?
Explanation: Explanation: The embankment of the Bhakra dam in India showed occurrence of numerous shear zones in them; the site could not be changed because of other reasons; hence it was decided to treat the shear zones by extensive excavations of the shear zones and back filling with cement grouting.

Question: 6. What are faults associated with?
Explanation: Explanation: Faults of any significance are always associated with earthquakes. The tectonic history of the area under consideration must be known thoroughly.

Question: 7. What is recommended to be introduced to the structures even on safe land?
Explanation: Explanation: Some factor of safety has to be introduced in the building even though the tectonic history indicates not movement of the surface or plate. It is always recommended to introduce factor of safety for high raised buildings or even buildings which are built on active seismic zones.

Question: 8. Studying tectonic history is basically like knowing
Explanation: Explanation: Study of tectonic history would virtually mean obtaining information about frequency of the earthquakes as also their magnitude and effects that they have left from time to time on the rocks of the region.

Question: 1. What is responsible for jointing of rocks?
Option B: b) Forces acting on the rock
Option C: c) Genesis and various forces acting on the rock
Explanation: Explanation: We may find quite a large proportion of outcrop of any of these rocks practically free from joints at some places, but at other places the same type of rock may be heavily jointed, showing cracks of greater variety. Hence it is not only genesis of the rocks which responsible for these structures but also the forces acting on them.

Question: 2. Fractures along which there has been no relative displacement is called
Explanation: Explanation: Joints are defined as divisional planes or fractures along which there has been no relative displacement.

Question: 4. The open joints are gradually enlarged due to
Explanation: Explanation: Open joints are those in which the blocks have been separated or opened up for small distances in a direction at right angles to the fracture surface. These may be gradually enlarged by weathering processes and develop fissures in the rocks.

Question: 5. The type of joint usually found is
Explanation: Explanation: There may be or may not be an opening up of blocks perpendicular to the joint planes. Hence the joints may be of open or close nature.

Question: 6. When the joints are prominent and extending for considerable depth they are called
Explanation: Explanation: The joints which are quite prominent and extending for considerable depth and thickness are called as continuous joints.

Question: 7. What are the continuous joints also called?
Explanation: Explanation: The continuous joints are also called often as master joints. Almost all joints are discontinuous in the strict sense because these disappear with depth in the crust of the earth.

Question: 8. The streaks or bands filling material in the rocks are called
Explanation: Explanation: In many cases, open joints get filled up by solutions of secondary materials which crystallize or precipitate there forming thin or thick streaks or bands of the filling material. These are simply called veins.

Question: 9. When the thickness is greater than 20 cm, the veins area called
Explanation: Explanation: The thin or thick filling material in the joints of the rocks are called as veins when thin and when their thickness exceeds 20 cm they are called fissure veins.

Question: 11. Pick the wrong statement.
Option A: a) A joint set is a group of joint surfaces
Option B: b) The surfaces trend in same direction
Option C: c) The surfaces have almost same dip
Option D: d) The joint surfaces do no trend in same direction
Explanation: Explanation: A joint set is a group of two or more joint surfaces trending in the same direction with almost the same dip.

Question: 12. Group of joint sets are called
Explanation: Explanation: A joint system is a group of two or more joint sets. A joint set is a group of two or more joint surfaces trending in same direction with almost same dip.

Question: 1. The classification which is not considered under study is
Explanation: Explanation: Joints have been classified on the basis of spatial relationships, geometry and genesis.

Question: 2. The type of joint which can be measured and mapped easily is
Explanation: Explanation: Systematic joints show a distinct regularity in their occurrence which can be measured and mapped easily.

Question: 3. Example of systematic joints are
Explanation: Explanation: Systematic joints occur in parallel or sub-parallel joint sets that are represented in the rocks at regular intervals. The columnar joints and the mural joints are examples of regular or systematic jointing.

Question: 4. How many groups are classified based on presence of regularities?
Explanation: Explanation: All joints are divided into two main groups on the basis of presence or otherwise of some regularity in their occurrence.

Question: 5. Which type of rocks are classified based on geometry?
Explanation: Explanation: In stratified rocks, joints are generally classified on the basis of relationship of their attitude with that of the rocks in which they occur.

Question: 6. How many types are further classified based on geometry?
Explanation: Explanation: Under the classification based on geometry, three types are recognized: Strike joints, dip joints, oblique joints.

Question: 7. The type of joint not studied under the geometry as basis is
Explanation: Explanation: Only three types of joints are studied under the classification of joints on the basis of geometry; strike joints, dip joints and oblique joints. Hade joint is not a type of joint.

Question: 8. What is the other name for diagonal joints?
Explanation: Explanation: Oblique joints are those joints where the strike of the joints is at any angle between the dip and the strike of the layers. These layers are also called diagonal joints when they occur midway between the dip and strike of the layers.

Question: 9. Joints parallel to bedding planes are called
Explanation: Explanation: In stratified rocks, some joints ma develop essentially parallel to the bedding planes. These are simply referred as bedding planes.

Question: 1. Joints running parallel to hinge lines are called
Explanation: Explanation: In the folded regions, joint orientation is conveniently described with reference to the hinge of the fold. Joints running parallel to hinge line are called radial joints.

Question: 2. In which rock, joints may be classified on the basis of their lineation?
Explanation: Explanation: In igneous and metamorphic rocks, the joints may be classified on the basis of their geometric relations with planar structures of those rocks such as lineation or cleavage.

Question: 3. Joints traverse linear structure right angles in which type?
Explanation: Explanation: Cross or Q joints are the joints which are traversing the linear structures at right angles.

Question: 4. Which are the joints parallel to linear structure?
Explanation: Explanation: Longitudinal or S joints, are the joints traversing parallel to the linear structure. In these rocks all the joint systems traversing at any other angular inclination with the linear structures are described as diagonal joints.

Question: 5. The joints developed due to tensile forces are
Explanation: Explanation: Tension joints are those, which have developed due to the tensile forces acting on the rocks. The most common location of such joints in folded sequence is on the outer margins of crests and troughs.

Question: 6. The type of joint occurring in igneous rocks during cooling is
